mapNodes.title: Vegetable Garden
mapNodes.description: The Campbell family, who owned Duntroon Estate, allotted a house and a parcel of land to each married worker on the estate. Blundells Cottage is the only remaining workers' cottage from that time period. In addition to the provision of lodgings, the Campbells granted workers a free half day on Saturdays to tend their gardens. Subsequent families also grew their own food for themselves and for sale. This garden bed represents the approximate site of Alice Oldfield's garden. The Sainsbury Family (in the 60s) grew potatoes and watermelons on the western side of the house.

mediaItems.caption: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Bread Oven
mapNodes.description: This exterior oven was built in an extension to the Cottage completed in 1888, the same year the eighth Blundell child was born. Flora would use this oven to bake bread for the family three times a week. On the other days, the family would eat damper. When she wasn't using it, Flora would let her neighbours, such as Mrs. Mayo, bake for their own families. Thousands of years ago, the local Aboriginal people would also make a type of bread or cake from ground Bogong Moths and Kangaroo Grass.

mediaItems.caption: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Ship's Tank
mapNodes.description: Once these tanks had served their purpose on board a ship, they were often purchased by rural households to be used as water tanks. The Blundells had three onsite, which they filled from the Molonglo River. They were eventually dumped in the lake bed as part of the clean-up and landscaping during the construction of Lake Burley Griffin.

mediaItems.caption: Ship's tank used as a water tank.
mediaItems.altText: One of the water tanks at Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Rainwater Tank
mapNodes.description: The ubiquitous Australian rainwater tank, used to catch water running off the roof, saved at least some trips to the river. This is the approximate location of the last tank onsite during Alice Oldfield's residence.

mediaItems.caption: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Fenceline
mapNodes.description: These posts represent the fenceline of the northern boundary of George Blundell's 125 acre leasehold. Property boundary fences were mandatory from the time of the Robertson Land Act of 1864. The Blundell children had to walk a long way to school when the St John's government school nearby closed and was re-opened at Narrabunda. Internal fencing of paddocks became more common in the 1880s, but was not a statutory requirement.

mapNodes.title: 1888 Extension Line
mapNodes.description: There is a visible change in the stone construction of the building on the western side. The southern section (with the chimney) is an extension built in 1888 and the stonework is not as refined as that of the original building. Note the profile of the original section - it is identical to the crofters cottages of western Scotland, where the original design and the stonemasons themselves came from.

mediaItems.caption: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.
mediaItems.altText: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.

mediaItems.caption: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.
mediaItems.credit: Wikicommons, unknown author, 1903, Leonard A Lauder collection of Raphael Tuck & Sons Postcards
mediaItems.altText: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.

mapNodes.title: Artemisia Plant
mapNodes.description:
Wormwood (Tree wormwood or Artemisia arborescens) were a popular plant in the 19th and 20th century because their leaves repel clothes insects.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup on wormwood plant out the front of the Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup on wormwood plant out the front of the Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Acknowledgement of Country
mapNodes.description: Families have occupied this land for thousands of years, long before the Cottage was constructed. The NCA acknowledges the traditional custodians of this land and pays their respects to their elders past, present and emerging.

mediaItems.caption: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
mediaItems.altText: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

mapNodes.title: Robert Campbell 1769–1846 - Founder of Duntroon
mapNodes.description: Originally from Scotland, Robert Campbell arrived in Sydney on the Hunter in 1798 as a wealthy merchant. When his ship The Sydney was wrecked, he was compensated in the form of rich, grazing land on the Limestone Plains, now Canberra. He built Duntroon House on his large Duntroon Estate in 1830, the first limestone cottage in the region. By 1860, George Campbell, Robert's son, and his wife Marrianne Campbell had moved into Duntroon House. They started a major building program on the estate which included workman's cottages for the newly arrived immigrant workers from Britain. Blundells Cottage was made from stone quarried from Black Mountain and Mount Ainslie and was based upon crofters cottages of Western Scotland.

mediaItems.caption: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow.
mediaItems.altText: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow

This garden bed represents the approximate site of Alice Oldfield's garden. The Sainsbury Family (in the 60s) grew potatoes and watermelons on the western side of the house.

mapNodes.title: Robert Campbell 1769–1846 - Founder of Duntroon
mapNodes.description: Originally from Scotland, Robert Campbell arrived in Sydney on the Hunter in 1798 as a wealthy merchant. When his ship The Sydney was wrecked, he was compensated in the form of rich, grazing land on the Limestone Plains, now Canberra. He built Duntroon House on his large Duntroon Estate in 1830, the first limestone cottage in the region. By 1860, George Campbell, Robert's son, and his wife Marrianne Campbell had moved into Duntroon House. They started a major building program on the estate which included workman's cottages for the newly arrived immigrant workers from Britain. Blundells Cottage was made from stone quarried from Black Mountain and Mount Ainslie and was based upon crofters cottages of Western Scotland.

mediaItems.caption: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow.
mediaItems.altText: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow

poiNodes.title: Vaccination Certificate
poiNodes.description: William and Mary Ginn and their two boys arrived in Sydney Cove on 23 July 1857 aboard the ship called The Alfred as assisted immigrants. All immigrants were required to be vaccinated against smallpox before their arrival in Australia. The voyage could be a perilous journey and some ships, like the Loch Ard, were wrecked off the coast of Victoria in 1878.

mediaItems.caption: Walter Ginn's vaccination certificate dated 7 November 1854.
mediaItems.altText: Walter Ginn's vaccination certificate dated 7 November 1854.

mediaItems.caption: Wreck of the Loch Ard near Sherbrook River, from Illustrated Sydney news and New South Wales Agriculturist & Grazier, 13 July 1878, p. 13.
mediaItems.credit: Accession Number H2002.150/51Phillip Doak Collection, State Library of Victoria
mediaItems.altText: Wreck of the Loch Ard near Sherbrook River, from Illustrated Sydney news and New South Wales Agriculturist & Grazier, 13 July 1878, p. 13.

poiNodes.title: Knuckles
poiNodes.description: Knucklebones is a game that has existed for thousands of years across many countries. Commonly, the ankle bones of a sheep are thrown up and caught in different ways. The winner is the first player to successfully complete a series of perscribed throws. In the 1800s, people often handmade their own toys and dolls rather than buying them in a shop. Can you find a game in every room at Blundells Cottage?

poiNodes.title: Inkwell, Bible and Book
poiNodes.description: William and Mary Ginn were the first occupants of the Cottage. Mary's arrival documents record that she was a literate house servant and that William (who could neither read nor write) was a labourer. William and Mary were presented with The Cottagers Family Prayers book on 11 April 1857 by the Rev. Charles Colson with his best wishes. St John the Baptist church would have been an integral part of community life in this district from its consecration in 1845.

mediaItems.caption: Mary Ginn's bible, inkwell and pen.
mediaItems.altText: Mary Ginn's bible, inkwell and pen.

mediaItems.caption: Church of St Johns Canberra, March 18 2007.
mediaItems.altText: Church of St Johns Canberra, March 18 2007.

poiNodes.title: Candle Mould
poiNodes.description: Poorer families had to make candles at home rather than buy them in a shop. By the 1850s, most families used paraffin or beeswax to pour into a mould like this. Can you find a source of light in every room at Blundells Cottage? How have lighting methods changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: At home in the 1860s, ironing without electricity was a hard job. Most plain metal irons were heated by a fire or on a stove and they often had a wooden handle so they could be held without getting too hot. At least two irons were needed: one to be in use and one to be re-heated on the fire or stove.

poiNodes.title: Produce Bags
poiNodes.description: Before plastic ware or prepackaged goods were available, people used cloth bags when buying and storing food. The bags were re-used and would have been refilled at the Duntroon store that issued supplies to employees. Can you find food containers in every room at Blundells Cottage? How have containers changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Tool Basket
poiNodes.description: William Ginn was a skilled labourer and was the Head Ploughman on the Duntroon Estate. He was respected by his employer, Charles Campbell, for his quiet manner and diligence. The Robertson Land Acts came into effect not long after William moved into the Cottage, enabling him to select two lots of 40 acres. In his lifetime, William went from a free employee migrant, to a tenant farmer, to a land owner.

mediaItems.caption: Tool basket, short-handled pick and a coffin plane.
mediaItems.altText: Tool basket, short-handled pick and a coffin plane.

mediaItems.caption: Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1861, Government of New South Wales.
mediaItems.altText: Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1861, Government of New South Wales.

poiNodes.title: Bed
poiNodes.description: This is the original bed that the Ginn family brought with them from England to Australia. It would have been stowed away on their ship, the Albert. Large trunks were used as bed bases for the children and bed rolls were placed on top. Have you ever travelled far from home? Journeys can be accompanied by feelings of apprehension, excitment, fear and sadness.

poiNodes.title: Baby's Cot
poiNodes.description: The Ginn family had two boys when they arrived in Australia: Walter and Henry. Baby Gertrude was born before they moved into the Cottage and Agnes some time after. It was common for goods like a cot to be shared in the commuity if they were no longer needed by a family.

poiNodes.title: Big Trunk
poiNodes.description: The Ginns would have experienced cramped conditions on their journey from England to Australia on a ship. Clothing and some supplies would have been stored in a canvas bag or small cabin trunk, for ready access, while the remainder of their possessions would have been stored in a trunk such as this. Passengers would have had limited access to their large trunks if weather conditions allowed.

mediaItems.caption: Storage trunk in the Ginn rooms.
mediaItems.altText: Storage trunk in the Ginn rooms.

poiNodes.title: Vaccination Certificate

The voyage could be a perilous journey and some ships, like the Loch Ard, were wrecked off the coast of Victoria in 1878.

about.text:
About the Cottage

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit, sed diam nonummy nibh euismod tincidunt ut laoreet dolore magna aliquam erat volutpat. Ut wisi enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exerci tation ullamcorper suscipit.

Opening times

10am–2pm every Saturday
Thursdays or Fridays (by arrangement) for school and group programs only

Location

Blundells Cottage, Wendouree Drive, Parkes, ACT 2600

Contact

Phone: 02 6272 2902
Email: nce@nca.gov.au

Bookings

Bookings can be made at: https://www.nca.gov.au/discover-and-learn/book-program

Heritage

Content to be confirmed

Education

Education kits, linked to the National Curriculum, are available for all ages at: https://www.nca.gov.au/discover-and-learn/education-resources
